tomato_bacterial_spot.description: Bacterial spot is a serious disease of tomatoes caused by Xanthomonas bacteria. It produces dark, raised spots on leaves, stems, and fruits, leading to defoliation and reduced yield.
prevention: Practice crop rotation with non-host plants
Maintain proper plant spacing for good air circulation
Keep the field clean and free from plant debris
treatment: Apply copper-based bactericides early in the season
Prune affected leaves and improve air circulation
Use streptomycin sprays where legally permitted

tomato_early_blight.description: Early blight, caused by Alternaria solani, is characterized by dark brown spots with concentric rings on older leaves. The disease can cause significant defoliation and reduce fruit yield.
prevention: Remove and destroy infected plant debris
treatment: Apply fungicides containing chlorothalonil or mancozeb
Maintain proper nutrition to help plants resist infection
Apply organic fungicides like copper or sulfur-based products

tomato_late_blight.description: Late blight, caused by Phytophthora infestans, is a devastating disease that causes large, dark brown patches on leaves and can quickly kill entire plants. It's infamous for causing the Irish Potato Famine.
prevention: Avoid overhead irrigation and wet foliage
Space plants properly for good air circulation
Monitor weather conditions for disease-favorable periods
Remove volunteer tomato and potato plants
treatment: Apply protective fungicides before disease onset
Remove and destroy infected plants immediately
Use systemic fungicides during high-risk periods
Harvest remaining healthy fruit if disease is present

tomato_leaf_mold.description: Leaf mold, caused by Passalora fulva, primarily affects tomatoes in greenhouses or high-humidity conditions. It appears as pale green to yellow spots on upper leaf surfaces and olive-green spores on lower surfaces.
prevention: Remove lower leaves to improve air flow
Use resistant varieties in greenhouse production
treatment: Apply appropriate fungicides at first sign of disease

tomato_septoria_leaf_spot.description: Septoria leaf spot is caused by Septoria lycopersici and is characterized by numerous small, circular spots with dark borders and light centers on leaves. It can cause severe defoliation.
prevention: Space plants for good air circulation
Mulch around plants to prevent soil splash
treatment: Apply fungicides at first sign of disease
Continue treatments every 7-10 days in wet weather

tomato_spider_mites.description: Spider mites are tiny arachnids that cause stippling on leaves, leading to yellowing and death of leaves. They thrive in hot, dry conditions and can rapidly reproduce.
treatment: Apply insecticidal soaps or neem oil
Use miticides if infestation is severe

tomato_target_spot.description: Target spot, caused by Corynespora cassiicola, produces circular brown spots with concentric rings on leaves, stems, and fruits. It can cause significant yield loss in warm, humid conditions.

tomato_mosaic_virus.description: Tomato mosaic virus causes mottled and distorted leaves, stunted growth, and reduced yield. It can be transmitted through seeds, tools, and human handling.
prevention: Wash hands after handling tobacco products
treatment: No cure available - remove and destroy infected plants
Plant resistant varieties in future seasons

tomato_healthy.description: Healthy tomato plants show vigorous growth, deep green foliage, and normal fruit development without any signs of disease or pest damage.
prevention: Regular monitoring for early detection of problems
treatment: Monitor for any signs of stress or disease

pepper_bacterial_spot.description: Bacterial spot on peppers, caused by Xanthomonas species, creates water-soaked spots on leaves and fruits that eventually become brown and necrotic.

apple_scab.description: Apple scab, caused by Venturia inaequalis fungus, is one of the most serious diseases of apple trees. It causes dark, scab-like lesions on leaves and fruits, significantly reducing fruit quality and yield.
prevention: Maintain good air circulation through proper pruning
Remove and destroy fallen leaves in autumn
Apply preventive fungicides before bud break
Maintain proper tree spacing in orchards
treatment: Apply fungicides at 7-10 day intervals during wet periods
Remove and destroy infected leaves and fruits
Use systemic fungicides for better control
Monitor and maintain fungicide schedule until harvest

apple_black_rot.description: Black rot, caused by Botryosphaeria obtusa fungus, affects apple trees causing leaf spots, fruit rot, and branch cankers. The disease can lead to significant crop loss and tree damage.
prevention: Remove dead or diseased wood during winter pruning
Apply protective fungicides during bud break
treatment: Prune out cankers and dead wood

apple_cedar_rust.description: Cedar apple rust, caused by Gymnosporangium juniperi-virginianae, is a fungal disease requiring both apple trees and cedar trees to complete its life cycle. It causes bright orange spots on leaves and fruits.
prevention: Remove nearby cedar trees if possible
Monitor weather conditions for infection periods
treatment: Apply fungicides when orange spots appear
Remove galls from cedar trees within vicinity
Continue fungicide applications in wet weather

potato_early_blight.description: Early blight in potatoes, caused by Alternaria solani, produces dark brown concentric rings on leaves. It typically starts on older leaves and can significantly reduce tuber yield.
prevention: Control soil moisture through proper irrigation
treatment: Apply approved fungicides at regular intervals
Consider early harvest if infection is severe

potato_late_blight.description: Late blight, caused by Phytophthora infestans, is a devastating potato disease that can destroy entire fields within days under favorable conditions. It causes dark, water-soaked lesions on leaves and tubers.
treatment: Apply systemic fungicides immediately upon detection
Increase spray frequency during wet weather
Harvest tubers early if disease threatens
Store tubers in cool, dry conditions

grape_black_rot.description: Black rot, caused by Guignardia bidwellii, is a serious fungal disease of grapes that affects leaves, shoots, and berries. Infected berries become mummified and can harbor the pathogen over winter.
prevention: Remove mummified berries and infected leaves
Train vines for optimal sun exposure
Apply dormant sprays in early spring
treatment: Apply fungicides at early shoot growth

grape_esca.description: Esca (black measles) is a complex disease caused by multiple fungi affecting the woody tissue of grapevines. It causes leaf striping, fruit spotting, and eventual vine decline.
treatment: Support plant health with proper nutrition
Consider vine replacement if severely affected

corn_common_rust.description: Common rust, caused by Puccinia sorghi, produces small, circular to elongated brown pustules on corn leaves. Heavy infections can reduce yield and grain quality.
treatment: Apply fungicides when rust is first detected
Time fungicide applications with weather conditions
Maintain plant health through proper nutrition

corn_northern_leaf_blight.description: Northern leaf blight, caused by Exserohilum turcicum, produces long, cigar-shaped gray-green to brown lesions on corn leaves. It can cause significant yield loss in susceptible hybrids.
treatment: Apply fungicides at first sign of disease
Document resistant varieties for future seasons

strawberry_leaf_scorch.description: Leaf scorch, caused by Diplocarpon earliana, produces purple to red spots on leaves that eventually develop necrotic centers. Severe infections can reduce fruit yield and quality.

strawberry_angular_leaf_spot.description: Angular leaf spot, caused by Xanthomonas fragariae, produces water-soaked, angular spots on leaves that become translucent and eventually reddish-brown.
